pros: The management is really good
cons: There's nothing bad about this company

review_title: Egomaniacs at the Top Destroying the Company
pros: Amazingly diverse work force among the rank-and-file workers. If you're queer, you will find such solidarity with your other rank-and-file coworkers like you've never experienced
cons: So many I can barely list. Executive leadership is only interested in their own prestige and will grind every other employee into the dirt rather than fix the issues they've caused. David Ernesto Munar has a runaway ego that prevents him from ever admitting he's done harm to people. CFO John McElwee is a reckless idiot. COO Steven Glass does not view employees as people, simply as metrics and continues to install new and pointless productivity metrics just to grind employees into dirt. Organization covers up sexual harassment in its ranks. The union busting here is disgusting. They flagrantly violate labor law by ignoring the National Labor Relations Act, OSHA. If you need ADA accommodations, good luck. Your manager will just bully you into quitting. Incompetent managers are promoted as long as they are cruel to their employees and endlessly loyal to David, the CEO. Again, loyalty to David is the ONLY thing they are interested in when hiring managers. This one man runs this organization like he is the king and everyone should be kissing his feet.

review_title: Great Organization to learn about Healthcare
pros: HBH is a great organization for people who want to get their foot in healthcare. It's small enough, so you get to know alot of people. However, it's big enough that you are able to learn from various practices. People are nice and friendly and VERY LGBT friendly. Also, HBH has the best PTO policy that I have ever had in my 7 year career. A little over a month just to start off.
cons: Since it's a small organization, promotions/pay raises can be limited. However, each department differs.

pros: close to home, help the community, grow my knowledge
cons: having to wear multiple hats in different sections of the department without proper compensation.

pros: If you are not party of the LGBTQ community your treated differently
cons: No support from HR they do not care about staff

pros: Work with under represented community in affirming ways Great relationship and networking opportunities
cons: Toxic leadership poor fiscal management lack of transparency in process and decision-making poor staff development severely under staffed

pros: friendly staff and welcoming nurses with great attitudes
cons: everything else and working here gave me anxiety

pros: Great benefits I loved the Comms team that I worked with I felt like the work I was doing really mattered to other people like me I didn't have to hide anything about my identity
cons: The direction that the CEO and ELT seem to be headed in means less of everything positive that I listed I've heard horror stories about the many others in clinic positions and how their departments are run I was laid off quite unexpectedly, after a lot of reassurance from the top that it wouldn't happen

job_title: Prenatal Case Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: I left after a few weeks so not much.
cons: I worked at hbh pre pandemic and when I returned post pandemic, it was a dystopian dumpster fire. Staff on the ground work really hard and so much of it isn't their fault at all- that level of disarray spoke volumes of executive staff.

pros: The direct service staff are some of the most brilliant advocates I have every met.
cons: The org has made some ethically questionable moves over the last few years.

review_title: Shameless and Harmful behavior in the name of profit
job_title: Behavioral Health Provider in Chicago, IL
pros: Amazing coworkers who are exceptional in their respective roles and love the community. Benefits are great. (Though, ELT is probably going to work to change that.) -pto, vacation time, continuing education, sick time -reimbursement for licensure, 1k continuing education
cons: The organization has lost all credibility and integrity. ELT values profit over people. One glance at Glassdoor and HBHWorkersUnited page shows you there has been mistake after mistake, harm after harm with absolutely no accountability. The executive leadership committee is made up of evil, money hungry yet incompetent people. They join Howard Brown for clout and pure corporate. These people will spend money on programs that don’t work, union busting law firms and PR teams but refuse to bargain in good faith with the union. They only seem to promote incompetent and harmful people to be on ELT. They cannot answer what trauma informed care is yet are making behavioral health decisions. Including spending money on a model that that allegedly cost 6 figures that no one asked for that they didn’t even end up using! They laid off over 10 therapists and had the audacity to say that these choices would not affect patient care.

pros: Benefits at Howard brown are comparable to private hospitals - great benefits and clients are amazing
cons: Poorly managed by leadership - it is too frequent that concerns are dismissed and your needs to unaddressed for several months before getting support from leadership this can be even related to pay increases that you are due for or role compensation once completing exams and certificates

pros: Most coworkers are delightful folks committed to LGBTQ+ healthcare
cons: Leadership is constantly dismissive of their employees Leadership engages in Union busting Leadership has no clear mission or vision for the organization aside from profit and does not align with our stated mission and vision Inequitable pay Manager discretion leads to discrimination Staff are overworked and underpaid which means that patient care suffers

pros: Strong nursing contract and benefits
cons: The executive leadership team is extremely toxic and blatantly profit driven

pros: Honestly none. Worst place I’ve ever worked. There are people in roles that have no clue what they’re doing and no prior experience in their role.
cons: Can’t say enough bad things about this place. STAY AS FAR AWAY AS YOU CAN!

pros: they pay a decent amount
cons: not a very supportive environment

pros: Wonderful, affirming coworkers and care teams. Unionized work force!
cons: Shockingly disorganized, lack of respect for clinical team input on work flows. Poor communication across departments and sites. Leadership is not patient or employee centered, and the organization is financially mismanaged.

pros: Being surrounded by culturally competent individuals who are passionate about empowering others and helping break barriers to care is just scratching the surface. Howard Brown really invests in its employees, ensuring your cup is continuously refilled with tools to be a better you. A true team mentality leading always from its heart.Amazing benefits and 401K contribution match. I was able to save up more than enough to purchase my first piece of property and pay myself back in the process while working for the organization.
cons: Always be mindful of various communication styles as you will come across all types. Also, practice self-care continuously as helping others align on their journey can take a toll on you. It is easy to be consumed and overwhelmed if you are not balanced and organized. Utilize your PTO. Clients and staff will trigger you at some point; we all have wounds in the healing process. This is not intentional. It's a realization that everyone's healing from something. We're all human and genuinely want the best for individuals and their journey as patients or staff members; just be true to yourself and open for enlightenment.

pros: Great co-workers and the mission of the organization!
cons: The top management, including the CEO and the CFO were asleep behind the wheel. They just now realized that the funding is drying out when they knew well it was coming for months. And now they are laying people off to save their own skin. Shameful!

pros: Really wonderful organization that does great work in the community. The employees that work there are extremely mission driven and care about providing great care for the patients
cons: Upper level management sucks. The amount of disorganization for such a large health care organization is astonishing.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: Lot of work for little pay. Union now.
cons: You can get laid off.

pros: There truly is nothing good to say about this organization.
cons: This place has huge issues around tokenization of people's identities and no respect for POC or women in general. Although it is run by a LatinX CEO, he may as well be a white man. It's sad and I would not advise ANYONE to work there!

job_title: Behavioral Health Professional in Chicago, IL
pros: Dedicated and passionate colleagues that care for the community
cons: Leadership destroys lives and exploits the communities by playing Monopoly with money that belongs in the community.

review_title: Poor pay, poor leadership, unfortunate failure for an underserved community
pros: Pros all fall under personal goals outside of the organization such as the fact you are working to assist an underserved community of LGBTQIA+ individuals.
cons:
Howard Brown operates on a "Pay Grid" meaning there are no performance based raises and you are locked into a certain rate regardless of seniority or performance. Pay is non-negotiable and is not competitive with similar organizations. 
Leadership is underqualified and uncaring in regards to the mission of Howard Brown, of which has become muddled from protecting self-image and sacrificing patient care and sensitivity for money. Decisions are based not on employee feedback or the needs of the community and more and more of the higher-ups are being replaced by CIS, straight individuals who lack empathy and experience with the LGBTQIA+ community. Howard Brown is now run as a "business." I am no longer proud to work at this organization of which is a mere shadow of its former self. Hoping for change.

pros: A positive attitude has been shown around the agency in the last year, and support has been offered to all employees. There is an open culture that offers different channels of communication where employees can talk and approach the leadership team without fear of being punished. It is an organization where you can trust that you will be heard, which helps motivation and productivity improve every day. Great mission, growth opportunities, and people that care for others!
cons: The agency is overgrowing and requires more talent, which represents a significant challenge for different units. Employees may perceive this challenge as a threat that causes gossip and results in low morale by few community members.

job_title: Regional Facilities Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: mood place to work everything is about feelings
cons: is about feelings you wont go up

pros:
-Generous PTO
-Good Benefits
-Inspiring Mission working to improve the lives of the LGBTQ community
cons:
-Disorganization throughout
-No accountability for people that don't do their jobs 
-Communication throughout the organization is atrocious
-Dysfunctional HR department
-Promotions aren't based on quality of work, how well you work with others or your commitment to the organization. How far you go in your career here depends on your VP and how much they like you. 
-Inconsistent compensation practices.
-Unwillingness to invest in professional development opportunities for staff.
-I worked for this organization for several years (over 5 years) and always got exceeds expectation on every performance review and the appropriate pay increase. When I finally left because I felt like I was being held back in my career, I found out I was replaced by a new hire making about 20% more than I did. It felt like a total punch to the gut and was proof that I was indeed being held back. Shady. Shady. Shady.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: Free lunches from blood thirsty drug reps, good PTO, affordable HMO insurance, decent 401k match
cons: Horrible management, horrible patients, toxic work environment, very little wage transparency, completely inadequate Covid responce, constant workflow changes, no consequences for abusive staff that have been reported repeatedly, insane workload, mediocre pay, complete company-wide disorganization. As a PSR, you are the front line for abuse from the patients for the many inadequacies at HBH, including the large number of mentally ill folk that use this clinic due to FQHC status. As a walk in clinic, folks will walk in for absolutely anything and everything, high on drugs, non-compliant with psych meds, etc. And as a PSR, it will be your job to negotiate for them to receive care. The level of care you can negotiate for patients is proportionate to how much the other staff like you and are willing to do you favors. Folks will come in needing housing, food, bus cards, and other resources where demand outpaces supply. It will be your job to find something, anything you can provide for folks. And you better do it fast or you'll get a rude yelp review. You will be considered the bottom of the HBH food chain, your feedback will not be listened to and will not impact workflows.

review_title: Terrible Management, High Turnover, Money First-Patient Second
job_title: Patient Services Representative II in Chicago, IL
pros: Howard Brown is potentially forming a Union.
cons: Howard Brown is on a pay grid so that means NO performance-based raises. You're locked in to a set salary per job title. Complete lack of communication, organization-wide, leaving workers at the ground-level to essentially "run things," and the primarily straight, cis senior management to collect a check.

pros: Community based care and outreach.
cons: This place is very toxic.

pros: You get to work with awesome queer folx, benefits are great.
cons: You get over worked at times because there's so much turn over. Leadership gets richer while the folx on the ground barely get the right support to sustain employees

job_title: Behavioral Health Professional (BHP) in Chicago, IL
pros: Strong mission, a lot of experience and speciality gain
cons: Requires a lot of bootstrapping. Not all staff is equally engaged with the mission.

pros: it’ll be pay check to paycheck, but better than no paycheck at all
cons: Low wages, HR does nothing for the employees

job_title: Patient Access Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: The water is filtered and the bathrooms are clean.
cons: Nothing is consistent for any position.

pros: Clinical and program staff are great and do amazing work with the community. It’s fulfilling work. Decent pay, good benefits, and great PTO (if you can actually use it)
cons: Run don’t walk from any job in administration here, especially on the external relations department.  Awful leadership and a toxic work culture. Turnover is constant and people can’t get out fast enough, mental breakdowns left and right. Everyone will talk about the importance of work life balance and nobody will mean it. The organization is growing and evolving way too rapidly and it’s chaotic. Leadership will throw whoever they need to under the bus to protect themselves and the organization.

pros: HB has some of the most dedicated and insightful staff working to diminish disparities in the LGBT community.
cons: SPACE. HB has grown very rapidly over the past decade and there are TONS of physical limitations in the space you work in. Some offices are crammed with four or more people; if one person stands up, moves, or takes a phone call, everyone feels it.

cons: It can be very high stress. Working for an NGO means you have to learn to work with the resources you have.

job_title: Medical Case Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Benefits medical dental vision fsa
cons: Social chatter Between coworkers can’t advance if your straight

pros: The employees at Howard Brown are very mission driven. This is a huge positive in terms of workplace culture. It is a negative in their passion and commitment are easily taken advantage of by senior leadership. Overall, though, it's a fantastic place to work because of shared goals and commitments. I loved working there right up to the very end of my tenure.
cons: Senior leadership changes have occurred too frequently in the last five years, making for instability and needless change.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: Great PTO, good overall benefits. OK starting salary, good access to public transportation, great environment for LGBTQ
cons: Heres the real deal w HBH. They are growing very quickly, while the core health will always be LGBTQ, their base, they also want to be known as a full service primary care provider, including women and kids health Psych, BHS, dental. They want to change their branding yet stay true to their core. There are only two or three power brokers in this organization. Real decision makers.  They say yes or no. I was shocked to see that so called managers, directors etc have no real decision making authority. Its hard to get things done.  There is very little opportunity for advancement unless you become licensed. I will say that the worst roles in this organization are, patient service rep, MA, call center, medical records.  The work life balance does not exist.  Schedule s can change daily, you think you can leave at one time but cant.  10 and 12 hr days are not uncommon. When you close is when last patient leaves.  Last patients are often critical and you can stay 1- 2 hours later just waiting for a last patient to make a followup appt. You are expected to help other areas when short handed plus handle incoming patients for 5-7 Drs. and possibly dental, BHS, Insurance, and other services providers. Patients are rude and expect you to always accomodate them, regardless if they respond to your request for information. Patients take complete advantage of HB. Many have no ID, Ins, copay, wont complete documentation and if you question them, they will file a complaint on you. Again the PSR role is the worst. Managers will bully you.  Some workers do ok. Others dont. Drs rule. Try it, if you like it, stay. If not leave. Many do

review_title: Organization does good work, management is chaotic
pros: The patients, and other employees are wonderful and make for a great experiance and some lifelong friends
cons: The organization does not apply the beliefs to the workers. Managment is chaotic. Oversight is minimal. Turnover is high. Any limit setting to create work/life balance is seen as an employee being inflexible.

cons: I do not have any CONS

pros: Promotes growth and professional development of your skills.

pros: Coming to work every day and not losing my job
cons: Finding out that everyone I have liked that worked there and had talent was fired or left in protest.

pros: Career advancement, pay scales, vacation, health insurance
